page.title: 07HISTORY IN HALLATON TODAY 1
page.content: Hallaton is a picturesque village with many signs of its long history still visible. It is mentioned in the Domesday Book as Heleton or Aleton. Perhaps the oldest place is Castle Hill, the site of a motte and bailey castle, which probably formed the centre of the estate owned by Geoffrey Alselin as described in Domesday. The village is compactly built with church, manor houses and farms centred round the Market Place or The Cross as it is known. On the Cross is a heavily built conical structure, possibly 500 years old called the Butter Cross from where dairy produce was served on market days. It was here where the weekly markets took place and the twice-yearly five day fair, one of the largest fairs in the country. The Cross is still the "centre" of the village.
